ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Multiple Sclerosis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: MRI confirmed a large plaque on the left lateral pons; ABR showed central signs (abnormal I-V interval) consistent with brainstem involvement.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Retrocochlear pathology
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Indicated by ABR findings (delayed Wave V, abnormal I-V interval) disproportionate to the peripheral hearing loss.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Cochlear pathology
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Initially considered due to sudden hearing loss, but ruled out as the sole cause by ABR interwave delays and MRI findings.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess the degree and configuration of the reported sudden hearing loss.
To evaluate speech recognition abilities in the affected ear.
To differentiate between cochlear and retrocochlear etiology given the asymmetry and sudden onset.
To visualize potential retrocochlear lesions or central pathology suggested by ABR abnormalities.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient presented with left moderate-to-severe sensorineural hearing loss. ABR testing revealed central abnormalities (prolonged I-V interval) despite the peripheral loss. Subsequent MRI confirmed a large plaque on the left lateral pons, consistent with Multiple Sclerosis affecting the dorsal cochlear nucleus.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear thresholds normal (0-10 dB HL). Left ear moderate to severe SNHL (approx 40 dB HL at 250 Hz sloping to 60-70 dB HL).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear recognition excellent (100%). Left ear recognition 84%.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Right ear normal. Left ear poorly defined morphology; Wave I present but delayed; Wave V discernible but delayed; I-V interwave interval abnormal/prolonged, indicating central involvement.

tests.name: MRI
tests.result_summary: Large plaque located at the lateral pons on the left side, likely compromising the left dorsal cochlear nucleus.

proposed_items: Referral to Neurology for management of Multiple Sclerosis
counseling_actions: Explain that the hearing loss and 'hissing' sounds are related to the brainstem lesion affecting the hearing nerve pathway
Discuss that ABR results indicated a problem further up the pathway which MRI confirmed
Coordinate care with neurology as the hearing loss is a symptom of the broader neurological condition

escalation.rationale_short: Diagnosis of Multiple Sclerosis confirmed by MRI; patient requires management of systemic neurological condition.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor progression of neurological symptoms and hearing status.
